top_comment.text:
I live in fl n I hate it....so many tourist,really hot summers,people stay 
mostly inside cause its so hot,you must have a car to get around, 
everything is really far from each other, really bad drivers,downtown 
Orlando is OK only during the night life early during the day its pretty 
boring, fl is for vacation or retirement﻿
top_comment.author: katie rodriguez

comments.text:
Yea I love my city n the fast pace lifestyle Yur right there's no place 
like home
comments.author: katie rodriguez

comments.text:
+katie rodriguez Ah, ok. That makes a little more sense. You probably miss 
home too. That's understandable. I'm from Louisiana, and my family spent a 
lot of time in Florida and all over the Gulf Coast when I was growing up, 
so I absolutely love Florida. I love the heat and humidity, the beaches, 
the theme parks, the state parks, and I have a lot of friends there. My 
wife is also from there. We're living in Utah right now, and we've enjoyed 
our time here, but it's not home, so after I graduate next year, we're 
moving to Florida to be near home and family. People tend to eventually 
move back home after living all around the world or country. It's in our 
nature. I've also lived in California, and I loved it there, but it's also 
not home. The Gulf Coast is where my and my wife's hearts are. I also love 
Florida, because it reminds me a lot of both Louisiana and California. To 
each his/her own. :)
comments.author: Michael Gisclair

comments.text:
Move up north and then you'll appreciate Florida more. ;) Trust me, I speak 
from experience.
comments.author: Michael Gisclair

top_comment.text:
I've been here two times and they were the best vacations I've ever had so 
far in my life! My first time was a week at Disney World. My second time we 
went on the Disney Dream and went to Universal afterwards. I really want to 
go back there!﻿
top_comment.author: Joshua Cueva

comments.text:
+punjaban284 Well the Disney Dream is a cruiseline that sails from Port 
Canaveral on the eastern coast of Florida. It salis to different 
destinations, but the one I went one was a 4-day 3-night trip stopping by 
Atlantis and Castaway Cay, a private island in the Bahamas owned by Disney. 
The ship itself has a nice swimming pool, a 3D movie theatre, fancy 
restaurants, sports area, live shows and performances, and even a water 
ride.

Now Disney World is a resort that holds 4 theme parks, 2 water parks, and 
31 hotels. The theme parks are the Magic Kingdom, Animal Kingdom, Epcot, 
and Hollywood Studios; and the water parks are Typhoon Lagoon and Blizzard 
Beach. The Magic Kingdom is almost the same as Disneyland in Anaheim, 
Florida with some different attractions. Disney's Animal Kingdom is a theme 
park based around animals, specifically African and Asian animals. Disney's 
Hollywood Studios is all about the movies (and yes Disney movies) where 
they have movie-based shows and attractions. Epcot stands for Experimental 
Prototype Community of Tomorrow. It has two themes; a land of the future, 
and a celebration of different countries called World Showcase. 

As for the hotels there are too many for me to say because I don't know all 
of them. But I'll put a link to what they have. All I can say is that every 
hotel is special because they have different themes to blend in with your 
vacation depending on what you choose from. They go from the great 
outdoors, Disney animated movies, African culture, etc. I can however share 
about the hotel I went to. I stayed at the Saratoga Springs Resort & Spa. 
It was a beautiful Victorian-styled resort that had two swimming pools, an 
arcade, spa, weight room, and restaurants. One thing I love about the 
hotels is that you can take a bus to any theme park and hotel, so u don't 
have to rent a car.

Just by typing all of this I feel inspired to go back and have fun. I hope 
you plan out a vacation soon that best fits you!

And here's a link to the hotels on the website.
https://disneyworld.disney.go.com/resorts/
comments.author: Joshua Cueva

comments.text:
+Joshua Cueva  what is the difference between disneywolrd and disneydream? 
which one is better....which hotel would u recommend
comments.author: punjaban284

captions.text:
Orlando is centrally located in the state
of Florida, with the Atlantic Ocean to the
east and the Gulf of Mexico to the west.

With over two million people, Orlando is the
state's third largest metropolis.

For thrill seekers, and parents wanting to
spend quality time with their kids, Orlando
means just one thing: action!
It is the place where imaginations run wild.

Each year over 50 million tourists escape
to the sunny city for a fun-packed holiday
in a world of make-believe.

Sure, there are some beautiful sculpture gardens,
botanic gardens, art museums, and inner city
attractions in Orlando,
but most people come here to visit theme parks!

They are scream provoking, laughter inspiring
and surprisingly educational.

They make you want to stay all day and go
again tomorrow.

They have so much to offer that you wonder
how you can fit it all in in one visit.

The Orlando Theme Parks are the ride of your
life!

The most famous local attraction, and perhaps
the most magical of all, is Walt Disney World.

The place to see all the cartoon characters
of your childhood come to life and introduce
them to your children.

Cuddles are also free at the Universal Resort,
and so is dancing!

You don't have to be a kid to love Wet 'n
Wild, one of the oldest and most popular water
parks in the country.

Whether you bring your friends, your family,
or come by yourself, you can splash around
all day without getting bored.
Dive into SeaWorld for more thrilling rides.

For a break from all the excitement, opt for
the calming experience of seeing manta rays
up close.

They live in perfect harmony with other big
marine creatures in the enormous aquarium.

Don't miss the dolphin show - it's really
spectacular!

Jump in to join these smart marine mammals
- an encounter you'll never forget!
Prepare to get your senses tricked at WonderWorks.

The upside-down building is full of daring
experiences that you shouldn't try at home.

Legoland, down south in the Winter Haven area,
is a supersized display of what can be achieved

if you had thousands of the plastic building
blocks we all grew up with.
Imagine building a whole city!

Zoom around in a tiny car, watch a Lego theater
show and admire the miniature replicas of

big Florida highlights such as The Kennedy
Space Center.

The actual Space Centre is to the east of
the city on Merritt Island.

Go and check out giant rockets and meet an
astronaut.

It's the only place in the world where you
can tour the launch areas of space shuttles.

To learn about the local wildlife, step inside
Gatorland.

It's your chance to see these large reptiles
up close and personal, including these extremely
rare white alligators.

Watch a nerve-wrecking crocodile wrestling
show, or - See you later alligator!

check out the less dangerous species in the
wildlife reserve.

Whiz kids will be drawn to the Science Center
where they can discover the inner workings
of magnetism, electricity and gravity.
There's a lot to learn here!

Florida is the Sunshine State and Orlando
offers year-round outdoor entertainment.

The summers are steamy and temperatures hardly
ever drop to freezing point in winter.

Yet, there is no cooler place than The Universal
Studios where The Wizarding World of Harry

Potter and the incredible super heroes of
your comic books come to life.

At night the Universal Orlando Resort lights
up with neon signs that will point you to
the many restaurants and live shows.

Come to Orlando for the family vacation of
a lifetime.

With all its natural beauty and theme parks,
the city has something to offer for everyone!
